title: Corporate and Contemporary
content:
Hi there, I was wondering if anyone had any ideas of a typefaces that are suited to body copy for corporate literature. Previously the designs in question used arial, but they are keen to 'push the boat out'(!) and go for something a little more contemporary and funky. any suggestions?

I'm talking about a company involved in finance etc so a suitable typeface should evoke solidarity and dependability, not too 'fun' for want of a better word.

Any thoughts at all are greatly appreciated.

R.
author: R27

comments.content:
Gee, it's hard to know where to start. So why don't we just push the boat out in a few different directions and you tell me which comes closest to your shore:

Serif: [Proforma](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=proforma) | Slab: [Caecilia](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=LH.108102.0.0) | Sans: [FF Strada](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=strada)

Thank you Stephen.

I would say Strada, only because I had a sans serif in mind, but on reflection a serif may just work. I would like to pursue the sans serif avenues first though.

Red27,

Perhaps you would be interested in checking out this thread [http://typophile.com/node/15086](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/typophile.com/node/15086 "http://typophile.com/node/15086") regarding the publication I'm working on which is also currently set in Arial. Hrant and Crossgrove had helpful comments.

K.
Thank you for your replies. Neo Sans & Fresco Sans are very pleasing. What about Myriad? Do you think it is too similar to Arial?

No, but it's almost as overused as Arial. Be different!

Near Fresco Sans: [Freight Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=GF.118889.0.0) | [Fedra Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=TQ.116887.0.0) | [ITC Legacy Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=LH.9268.0.0) | [Cronos Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=LH.114165.0.0)

On the Neo Sans side of the lake: [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=PRC.119254.0.0) | [Sophisto](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_sophisto_ss.html) | [Zemestro](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=M.118552.0.0)

Klavika I like! Thank you so much for your help everyone, i appreciate it.

R.

Heading for the shores of Klavika: [Stainless](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=stainless) | [Morgan](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/vllg.com/Feliciano/Morgan/mudTyper+Weights/) | [Cholla](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=cholla)
I have Stainless, never considered using it for body copy, nice for logo type use in the past. Worth a look. Thanks.

Give Linotype Compatil a look too.

hhp

_Give Linotype Compatil a look too._

Errr... I beg to differ, my esteemed colleague, but in my humble opinion Linotype Compatil... well... how to say this? It's not exactly the best type system around, to put it _very_ mildly.

I've licensed Sophisto and used it for the corporate identity of a regional hospital. It works brilliantly both as a display and a text face in a wide variety of applications, and has all the necessary bells and whistles to set even the most demanding corporate material.

And what about [Galaxie Polaris](http://web.archive.org/web/20120418090531/http:/www.vllg.com/Village/GalaxiePolaris/mudTyper+Weights/)? More generous in width, a nice tension in the superellipse curves, has all the feature-rich OpenType goodness, and it's very subtle in its modernity. A sure winner.
BTW You can trust Stephen on Klavika. Man does that one look good!

I guess I like it mostly because it tries so hard. Most people who don't like it don't like it for bad reasons, including envy. But I admit Yves can't be one of those people. Well, just look at it, at least - and don't play it too safe.

hhp
